One to four years after operation HSV gave a significantly better result than TV + P (/7 < 0.05) and the recurrent ulcer rate was 5.4% after each operation [1] .

The standard acid reflux test [1] using an intra-oesophageal pH probe allows only limited physical activity. We have developed an acid reflux provocation test (ARPT) using radiotelemetry capsules in freely mobile patients. An untethered pressure sensitive radiotelemetry capsule records intragastric pressure whilst a pH sensitive radiotelemetry capsule tethered in the distal oesophagus monitors reflux. A series of standardized exercises which raise intragastric pressure and also involve postural changes (weight lifting, leg raising, stooping) are performed before and after a standard meal.

Eight normal subjects and 16 patients with symptomatic gastro-oesophageal reflux were studied. Reflux in normal subjects was infrequent, median number of episodes 0.5 (range 0-5), median duration 1.3 mins (range 0-12.5) when compared with symptomatic patients, median number of episodes 3.0 (0-9) (u = 21, p<0.01) and median duration 8.86 mins (range 0-76.4) (u = 13, p<0.001).

In the normal group reflux was provoked on exercise in 4 subjects only after food (x = 5.3, p<0.05). Before food exercises provoked reflux in only 2 patients whereas 12 of the group refluxed post-prandially (x = 12.6, p<0.001).

Radiotelemetry was acceptable to patients and has proved useful in the evaluation of symptomatic reflux. Our hypothesis was that either an artificial valve [1] or reversed ileal loop might improve intestinal absorption and slow transit. We tested it in dogs after colectomy and low ileo-rectal anastomosis (IRA).

Body weight, xylose absorption, serum albumin, folate, vitamin B12, calcium, urea and electrolytes, full blood count, faecal weight and mouth to anus transit time [2] were measured before operation. The dogs then randomly underwent either IRA alone (control, C, n = 7), IRA with a 10 cm reversed loop (IRA + RL, n = 6) or IRA with an artifical valve (IRA + v, n = 6). Body weight, haematological estimations and faecal chemistry were measured weekly for 3 months post operatively. Xylose absorption and transit time were measured a minimum of 2 months after operation.

Body weight decreased significantly after each type of operation. There was no difference however, between (IRA + RL) and C or (IRA + v) and C. Likewise, haematological and faecal measurements after both test operations did not differ significantly from C or from pre-op, measurements. The Grosfeld valve prevented the reduction in transit time that occurred after the control operation, whereas the reversed loop did not.
Use of such a valve in combination with mucosal proctectomy might slow transit, but is unlikely to improve absorption. It seems worthy of further study.
